reviews.reviewText:
Napier Museum is truly a gem in the heart of Thiruvananthapuram. It‚Äôs a great place to take a relaxed walk, unwind, and enjoy some peaceful moments amidst nature‚Äîeven while being right in the middle of the city. The area is quite spacious, making it ideal for peaceful seating, thoughtful discussions, or simply soaking in the serene atmosphere.

From big to small, famous to local, museums give us places to think, grow, learn, wonder, and feel. Few cultural institutions have remained as important as museums over the decades. They preserve and promote social interests as diverse and unique as the people who visit them‚Äîand Napier Museum is no exception.

A night walk here is something truly special‚Äîthe calm surroundings, the cool breeze, and the beautifully lit pathways create a soothing ambiance that‚Äôs perfect for reflection or quiet conversations.

Whether you‚Äôre looking to reconnect with history, enjoy quiet time outdoors, or just take a refreshing stroll, Napier Museum offers something special for everyone. A must-visit for both locals and travelers alike.

One of the popular museums situated in the heart of the city and within the complex next to the famous Trivandrum zoo. One needs to buy a ticket to enter the museum and there is a paid parking facility available nearby.
The architecture of the museum and the park around captivate anyone very easily to visit it from afar. There are sculptures, displays and paintings inside but a limited experience. The place needs more maintenance and the continuous audio ads disturb the peaceful environment of the park.

Napier Museum: Where History, Nature & Calm Come Together üèõÔ∏èüåøüïäÔ∏è

It‚Äôs an experience that deserves an entire day to truly absorb. Spread across a huge, well maintained space, the place is spotlessly clean and beautifully organized, offering a calm escape right in the city.

The museum itself is free to enter, while the adjoining zoo entry costs just ‚Çπ50, which also includes a locker facility for bags and even plastic bottles a thoughtful touch for keeping the space clean. The zoo is expansive, and right outside, a small caf√© serves as the perfect refresher after a walk.

What makes this venue special is the balance it offers: while the exhibits and zoo engage your curiosity, the grounds themselves invite you to slow down. There are plenty of shaded spots and tree-side seating areas, making it easy to pause, rest, or just take in the serene atmosphere. Despite the outside heat, the entire space feels naturally cooler, adding to the comfort.

Whether you‚Äôre interested in history, looking to enjoy a day amidst nature, or simply searching for a peaceful retreat, Napier Museum is one of those rare places where you can do it all at once.

Atmosphere is nice, nicely maintained garden. Inside is a bit old, some of the beam concrete have already fell down from the ceiling. You can look into the past there are some ancient artifacts. Also there's a dedicated staff to guide us through them. You can take photos but need permission to take videos!!! Idk weird, anyways spend some good time there, won't be disappointing.

The Napier Museum in Trivandrum is a beautiful blend of history and architecture. The Indo-Saracenic design, colorful stained-glass windows, and peaceful garden surroundings create a serene atmosphere. The museum houses fascinating artifacts like bronze idols, ivory carvings, and historical weapons. A short but enriching visit for anyone interested in Kerala‚Äôs cultural heritage.

Napier Museum is a meticulously organized and captivating venue that highlights India's extensive cultural legacy. The museum features ancient statues dating back over 2000 years, alongside an impressive array of coins, sculptures, and weaponry. With a wealth of exhibits to explore, it offers a truly enriching experience. One cannot help but feel immense pride in witnessing the advanced knowledge and creativity of our forebears. The museum is beautifully preserved, complemented by a well-kept landscape surrounding the main structure. Centrally located, it is highly recommended for tourists and students alike to delve into and appreciate history!

"I recently had the pleasure of visiting the Napier Museum in Trivandrum and was thoroughly impressed. The museum is a beautiful example of Indo-Saracenic architecture, and its stunning red and white exterior is a sight to behold.

Inside, the collection is a fascinating journey through Kerala's rich history and culture. The bronze sculptures, ancient musical instruments, and intricate ivory carvings are all beautifully preserved and displayed. I particularly enjoyed the section on traditional Kathakali costumes and the impressive collection of temple chariots.

The grounds surrounding the museum are equally lovely, providing a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle. The lush green lawns, blooming flowers, and the nearby Trivandrum Zoo make for a perfect day out.

The staff were friendly and helpful, and the museum was clean and well-maintained. The Napier Museum is a true gem in Trivandrum, offering a wonderful blend of history, art, and nature. It's a must-visit for anyone interested in the cultural heritage of Kerala.

Nestled in the heart of Trivandrum, the Napier Museum is a graceful blend of heritage architecture and cultural riches. Built in 1880, this red‚Äëbrick Indo‚ÄëSaracenic marvel fuses Gothic gables, Kerala sloping roofs, Chinese minarets, and Italianate detailing - a feast for architecture lovers.

Stepping inside, you‚Äôll discover a treasure trove: over 550 artifacts ranging from temple chariots, bronze idols, Kathakali masks, and ivory carvings to a fascinating Japanese leather shadow‚Äëplay collection depicting the Mahabharata and Ramayana.

History buffs will appreciate the coin gallery boasting more than 5,000 coins from South India, Persia, Rome, and beyond. Highlights include an 8th‚Äëcentury Vishnu idol, the Sword of Velu Thampi Dalawa, and rare bronze and wooden sculptures.

One of the most charming features is the museum‚Äôs natural air‚Äëconditioning double‚Äëwalled ventilation and stained glass windows keep it cool even on warm days.

The museum forms part of a fascinating complex alongside the Thiruvananthapuram Zoo (Established in 1857), the Natural History Museum, Aquarium and the Sree Chitra Art Gallery,  enriching your visit with diverse experiences

Tips for your visit:
Visit early on a weekday to avoid crowds, allocate a minimum of 2 hours for the full experience.
Open from 10‚ÄØam - 4:45‚ÄØpm; closed on Mondays and some public holidays.
Tickets are budget‚Äëfriendly: approx ‚Çπ20 for adults (Indian) and ‚Çπ10 for kids.

sources.snippet: Thiruvananthapuram which was previously called Trivandrum is an ancient city with trading tradition dating back to 1000 BC. I recently visited the Thiruvananthapuram Zoo, Museum, and Aquarium, and it was a truly delightful experience. The zoo is beautifully maintained with a wide variety of animals, from majestic tigers to exotic birds, all kept in spacious and natural enclosures. The lush greenery and clean surroundings made the walk even more enjoyable. The museum was equally fascinating, offering a rich glimpse into Kerala‚Äôs cultural and historical heritage through its detailed exhibits and artifacts. The aquarium, though smaller, was well-organized and showcased a lovely collection of marine life. I was especially impressed by how educational yet entertaining the whole visit was. The place is perfect for families, students, and anyone who appreciates nature and history. I absolutely loved my time there and would highly recommend it to others visiting Thiruvananthapuram.

The ticket for the zoo and swara art gallery was 30-40 something .... and zoo and aquarium ticket was also separate....in total you will need to buy 3 tickets

I visited Thiruvananthapuram Zoo today, and it was a truly wonderful experience. The moment I walked in, I was impressed by how green, peaceful, and clean the entire zoo is. The big trees gave plenty of shade, and the pathways were wide and well maintained, which made walking around very pleasant. It felt like stepping into a calm natural space right in the middle of the city.

The animals were the real highlight of today‚Äôs visit. I spent a lot of time watching the Royal Bengal Tigers and Asiatic Lions‚Äîboth looked majestic and powerful, and it was amazing to see them so close. The giraffes were another star attraction, tall and graceful, and they caught everyone‚Äôs attention. I also enjoyed seeing the Indian One-Horned Rhinoceros, which is rare and exciting to witness in person. The zebras, with their unique stripes, were fascinating, and of course, the elephants were a joy to watch as always. The hippos relaxing in water and the graceful herds of deer added even more charm to the visit.

The bird section was full of life and color. Today I was especially amazed by the macaws, parrots, and hornbills‚Äîthey were so vibrant and active. The peacocks were beautiful too, adding a touch of elegance to the aviary. I also walked through the reptile house, where I saw crocodiles, snakes, and other reptiles. It was both exciting and educational. Every enclosure felt thoughtfully designed, and I appreciated how natural the surroundings looked.

Another thing I noticed during today‚Äôs visit was how well the place is maintained. The enclosures were clean, the animals looked healthy, and the zoo staff clearly put effort into keeping the environment neat. There were enough resting spots and drinking water points, which made the visit comfortable even though I spent a good amount of time exploring. The ticket price was very affordable for the quality of the experience.

After the zoo, I also took a quick look at the Natural History Museum and Sree Chitra Art Gallery nearby, which made the trip even more meaningful. Both are located right next to the zoo and add great value if you want to make it a complete day outing.

Overall, today‚Äôs visit to Thiruvananthapuram Zoo was fantastic. It‚Äôs a place where you can relax, learn, and enjoy the beauty of nature and wildlife all at once. I left with great memories, and I would definitely recommend this zoo to anyone visiting Thiruvananthapuram. üåøü¶íüêÖü¶ìü¶úüêò

sources.snippet:
Painting by Raja Ravi Varma depicting Richard Grenville being greeted by Visakham Thirunal, with Ayilyam Thirunal of Travancore at Thiruvananthapuram in early 1880s
 Thiruvananthapuram is an ancient region with trading traditions dating back to 1000 BCE.[12] The city was a trading post for spices, sandalwood and ivory.[13] The early rulers of the city were the Ays and after their fall in the 10th century, the city was captured by the rulers of Venad. In 1729, Marthanda Varma founded the princely state of Thiruvithamkoor and Thiruvananthapuram was made the capital in 1745 after shifting the capital from Padmanabhapuram in Tamil Nadu.[15] In the mid-19th century, the city was under the reign of Swathi Thirunal and Ayilyam Thirunal. An observatory was established in 1837 with the Oriental Research Institute & Manuscripts Library and the University College established in 1873.

This museum is a peaceful and informative place to explore, especially if you're interested in nature and wildlife. Located near the zoo and Napier Museum, it‚Äôs surrounded by trees and gardens that give a calm feeling even before you enter.

Inside, the museum is well-organised with separate sections for birds, mammals, reptiles, insects, fossils, and tribal life. You‚Äôll see lifelike models of animals, skeletons, and preserved specimens displayed with proper descriptions. One of the most interesting parts is the fossil gallery, which includes ancient tree trunks and other rare finds.

The building itself has an old charm, and the exhibits are arranged in a way that makes it easy to walk through and learn. It‚Äôs a good place for kids and students, but adults who enjoy learning will also find it engaging. It usually takes around one to two hours to see everything.

Photography is not allowed inside, and there is no cafeteria, but the museum is clean and the staff are helpful. There‚Äôs also a small garden with dinosaur statues that adds a playful touch, especially for children.

If you enjoy learning about nature or want to spend a quiet and meaningful afternoon in the city, this is definitely a good place to visit.

I was absolutely thrilled to visit the Natural History Museum in Trivandrum! As a history enthusiast, I was blown away by the vast collection of artifacts and exhibits that showcase the rich cultural and natural heritage of Kerala.

From the moment I stepped inside, I was struck by the stunning architecture of the building itself, which is a beautiful blend of traditional and modern styles. The museum's layout is thoughtfully designed, making it easy to navigate and explore the various galleries.

The exhibits are incredibly well-curated, with detailed labels and descriptions that provide a wealth of information about each artifact. I was particularly fascinated by the ancient stone sculptures, bronze idols, and traditional Kerala murals on display. The museum's collection of tribal artifacts and traditional crafts was also impressive, offering a glimpse into the lives of Kerala's indigenous communities.

What I appreciated most about this museum was the way it weaves together the natural and cultural history of the region. The exhibits on Kerala's flora and fauna, including the stunning taxidermy displays, were just as engaging as the historical and anthropological exhibits. It was amazing to see how the museum highlights the interconnectedness of human and natural history.

The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, and the museum's facilities were clean and well-maintained. Overall, I would highly recommend the Natural History Museum in Trivandrum to anyone interested in history, culture, or the natural world.

Vizhinjam Rock-Cut Cave, located near the coastal town of Vizhinjam in Thiruvananthapuram district( Near to vizhinjam police station ) This small yet significant cave is renowned for its ancient rock-cut sculptures and inscriptions, making it a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, archaeologists, and tourists.The Vizhinjam Rock-Cut Cave dates back to the 8th century AD and is believed to have been built during the reign of the Ay dynasty, a prominent ruling dynasty in southern Kerala. Kowdiar Palace, located in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is the official residence of the Travancore Royal Family. Built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a wedding gift for his sister, Karthika Thirunal Lakshmi Bayi, the palace remains a significant historical landmark.

Architecture and Features

The palace is a three-story structure with over 150 rooms, showcasing a blend of Kerala and Dravidian architectural styles.

It is set on a lush estate covering about 100 acres, offering a serene atmosphere away from the city's hustle and bustle.

Kowdiar Palace is home to Kerala‚Äôs very first elevator, imported from Italy, and it is still fully operational today.

Current Status

Kowdiar Palace continues to serve as a private residence for members of the Travancore Royal Family.

Entry to the palace interiors is not permitted for the public.

Visitors are welcome to view and admire the palace from the outside, but access beyond the gates is restricted.

Visitor Guidelines

If you plan to visit, you can enjoy the magnificent view of the palace from outside the premises.

Since public entry is not allowed, it is advisable to respect the privacy of the residents and avoid attempting to enter.

Kowdiar Palace stands as a proud reminder of Kerala‚Äôs rich history and cultural heritage, serving as a living testimony to the legacy of the Travancore royal lineage.

Kowdiar Palace is a stunning architectural marvel and a significant historical landmark in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. Built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a gift to his sister, Maharani Karthika Thirunal Lakshmi Bayi, on her wedding, the palace showcases a blend of traditional Kerala and European styles. Here are some fascinating facts about Kowdiar Palace
Architecture: The palace features a three-storied structure with over 150 rooms, lush gardens, and a unique blend of Kerala and European architectural styles.
History Kowdiar Palace served as the royal residence of the Travancore royal family and holds immense historical value, reflecting the region's rich cultural heritage.
Visiting HoursThe palace is open from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM, but entry is restricted as it's the private residence of the royal family. Visitors can observe and photograph the architecture from the gate.
Location Kowdiar Palace is located 4 kilometers from the city center, 5 kilometers from Thiruvananthapuram Central Railway Station, and 7.5 kilometers from Thiruvananthapuram International Airport.
Significance The palace is not just an architectural monument but a testament to the lives and legacy of the Travancore dynasty, which played a crucial role in shaping Kerala's history and cultural identity.

While the palace is not open to the public for interior visits, its exterior and beautifully maintained gardens offer a glimpse into the grandeur and majesty of Kerala's royal past .

The Kowdiar Palace is a historic palace located in Thiruvananthapuram (Trivandrum), Kerala, India. Built in the early 20th century, it served as the official residence of the Travancore royal family.

Architecture and Design
The palace showcases a unique blend of traditional Kerala and European architectural styles:

- *Travancore style*: The palace features traditional Travancore-style architecture, with sloping roofs, wooden ceilings, and intricate carvings.
- *European influence*: The palace also incorporates European-style elements, such as ornate furnishings, chandeliers, and landscaped gardens.

History
The Kowdiar Palace has played a significant role in Kerala's history:

- *Royal residence*: The palace was built in 1934 as the official residence of Maharaja Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma, the last ruling monarch of Travancore.
- *Historic events*: The palace has witnessed several historic events, including the signing of the Travancore-Cochin merger agreement in 1949.

Current Status
Today, the Kowdiar Palace is:

- *Museum*: The palace has been converted into a museum, showcasing the history and culture of the Travancore royal family.
- *Tourist attraction*: The palace is a popular tourist destination, attracting visitors from across the world.
- *Cultural events*: The palace hosts various cultural events and festivals throughout the year, promoting Kerala's rich cultural heritage.

This grand three-storey palace was built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a wedding gift for his sister, reflecting both royalty and family pride  . With over 150 rooms, it blends the simple elegance of Kerala architecture with hints of Dravidian influence and even touches of European design like tall steeples and a wooden lift  .

Set on a small hillock and surrounded by lush greenery, the building stands out in the city, its six towers visible from afar  . It was built with respect to Vastu Shastra and oriented to welcome monsoon breezes, showing how practical design and beauty were both important  . Inside, long corridors and high ceilings, carved wooden beams, and large halls hint at the royal gatherings and cultural events that took place here  .

Though visitors can‚Äôt enter, it still feels like walking through history. You can admire the elegant fa√ßade, spot the wood‚Äëlift shaft, and imagine the palace in its heyday. Nearby gardens hold the king‚Äôs burial site, which adds quiet meaning to the place  .

The palace remains the private home of the Travancore royal family, especially the descendants of the Maharajah‚Äôs sister  . Seeing it from the outside gives a sense of Kerala‚Äôs royal heritage, smart design, and how tradition and daily life once united here.

If you drive or walk past, take time to slow down and notice the architecture, the breeze‚Äëfriendly layout, the historical importance, and the idea of home it conveys‚Äîeven without entry, it leaves a memorable impression.

reviews.reviewText: The concept of a 'Museum' gains significant value when the treasured heirloom artifacts of a Royal Family are exhibited within their original palace! The atmosphere is exceptional, amplifying the visual appeal of each display. Participating in a guided tour proves to be more fulfilling than exploring independently, as there is a wealth of history and interesting facts associated with each item. It typically requires over an hour and a half to thoroughly appreciate every artifact, but the experience is undoubtedly worthwhile. The visit was captivating. The palace, constructed by Maharaja Swathi Thirunal, provides an in-depth exploration of Kerala‚Äôs historical and cultural landscape. The wooden architecture, elaborate carvings, and particularly the distinctive horse motifs (which lend the palace its name) are breathtaking. Strolling through the palace felt akin to traveling back in time, with exquisite artifacts, paintings, and royal memorabilia offering insights into the life of the Travancore royal family. The guides were well-informed and contributed essential context to the exhibits, rendering the tour both educational and engaging. Although photography is prohibited, which may disappoint some visitors, it serves to protect the artifacts. In summary, Kuthiramalika is an essential destination for those passionate about history and architecture. Puthen Malika Palace, also referred to as Puthen Malika Museum, is an essential site to visit in Thiruvananthapuram! This magnificent palace, erected in the 19th century, exemplifies the stunning architecture of Kerala and its rich royal heritage. The intricate wooden carvings and beautiful murals are visually captivating. Every corner narrates a story, and one can truly appreciate the craftsmanship that went into its creation.

Thiruvananthapuram Central Railway Station is superbly located in the heart of the city, making it a convenient hub for travelers. The proximity to the bus station and other transportation options is a major plus, allowing for easy connectivity. The station's central location and accessibility make it an ideal starting point for exploring the city. The station's architecture is impressive. Trivandrum Central Railway Station is one of the busiest and most important railway stations in Kerala, and it truly lives up to its reputation as a major hub. Located right at the heart of Thampanoor, the station is well connected to Chalai Bazaar, bus stands, and other prime areas of the city, making it very convenient for travelers.

The station building is historic yet modern in its facilities. The platforms are spacious, well-maintained, and equipped with digital display boards that provide clear information about arrivals and departures. Waiting areas are clean, with comfortable seating, and there are plenty of food stalls, tea shops, and small restaurants nearby for refreshments. The ticket counters and online booking kiosks are organized, and staff are generally helpful in guiding passengers.

Another big advantage is its connectivity ‚Äì trains from here cover almost all major destinations across India, from Chennai, Bangalore, and Hyderabad to long-distance trains to Delhi, Mumbai, and Kolkata. For tourists, it is also the gateway to exploring the charm of Trivandrum, including Kovalam Beach, Padmanabhaswamy Temple, and nearby attractions.

Security is good with CCTV surveillance, and announcements are regular and clear. Parking space is available, though during peak hours it can get crowded. Overall, Trivandrum Central is a clean, well-managed, and traveler-friendly railway station that offers a smooth experience whether you are arriving, departing, or just passing through.
Trivandrum Central Station is one of the cleanest, most organized railway stations I've visited in India. The staff is helpful, the announcements are clear, and the connectivity. Neat and clean

Thiruvananthapuram Central Railway Station (TVC), situated in the heart of Kerala‚Äôs capital city, is not only the busiest railway station in the state but also a crucial gateway connecting southern India to major destinations across the country. Established in 1931, the station is renowned for its colonial-era architecture, which stands as a reminder of the city‚Äôs historical significance while blending seamlessly with modern infrastructure. The station has five well-maintained platforms that efficiently manage both long-distance express trains and local passenger services, catering to a daily influx of thousands of commuters, tourists, and business travelers. TVC is equipped with numerous passenger-friendly amenities, including air-conditioned waiting halls, retiring rooms, escalators, elevators, digital baggage lockers, and multiple computerized ticket booking counters, ensuring convenience and comfort for all travelers. Its strategic location adjacent to the KSRTC Bus Station Complex enhances connectivity, allowing passengers easy access to buses, taxis, and auto-rickshaws for onward travel within the city or to nearby regions. The station is also part of a large-scale redevelopment initiative by the Southern Railway, aimed at transforming it into a modern, world-class transport hub while preserving Kerala‚Äôs cultural and architectural essence. This project includes multi-modal integration, improved passenger facilities, and aesthetic enhancements inspired by local art and heritage. Overall, Thiruvananthapuram Central Railway Station exemplifies a perfect blend of history, modernity, and strategic utility, serving as a landmark of the city and a vital node in India‚Äôs railway network, ensuring smooth, reliable, and comfortable travel experiences for millions of passengers every year.

reviews.reviewText: Koyikkal Palace is a calm and beautiful place in Kerala. The palace is built in the traditional Kerala style with wooden walls and sloping roofs. Koyikkal Palace in Nedumangad is  a peaceful place with serious old-world vibes. It‚Äôs not one of those massive royal palaces, but what it lacks in size, it makes up for in charm and history.

The building itself is this beautiful old Kerala-style structure with sloping tiled roofs and wooden beams‚Äîsuper traditional and photogenic. You can literally feel the history in the air. It was built way back in the 1600s.

Inside, there are museums. The Folklore Museum has some really cool stuff like old musical instruments, traditional lamps, costumes, and even tools people used ages ago. On the ground floor is the coin museum, Ancient coins collections are there. The place isn‚Äôt crowded at all‚Äîperfect if you want a quiet, thoughtful afternoon. The gardens around the palace are also nice, and it‚Äôs a great spot if you‚Äôre into photography, culture, or just want a chill outing away from the usual city spots.

Koyikkal Palace in Nedumangadu is a beautiful historic spot that perfectly blends culture and architecture. The palace is well-maintained, and the museum inside is very informative, showcasing traditional Kerala artifacts, coins, and antiques. The calm and peaceful surroundings make it a great place to spend some quiet time while exploring history. A must-visit for anyone interested in Kerala‚Äôs heritage.

Koyikkal Palace, Trivandrum

Koyikkal Palace, located in Nedumangadu, near Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is a historical palace built in the 17th century for Umayamma Rani of the Venad royal family. This traditional Nalukettu-style palace is known for its unique architecture and serves as a historical and cultural museum under the Kerala State Archaeology Department.

The palace houses two museums:

1. Folklore Museum ‚Äì Showcasing traditional musical instruments, household utensils, and rare manuscripts that provide insights into Kerala‚Äôs cultural heritage.

2. Numismatics Museum ‚Äì Displaying an extensive collection of ancient coins, including the rare Ottaputhan, Kaliyugarayan Panam, and coins from the Roman and Mughal periods.

Surrounded by lush greenery, Koyikkal Palace is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and those interested in Kerala‚Äôs royal past.
Calm and piece full atmosphere to spend at cheap cost. A well maintained palace and its pride to us. We can spend much more time we want. For me it was wonderful experience

If you‚Äôve been to the Keralam History and Heritage Museum, the vibe is pretty similar ‚Äî except the Keralam Museum has more stunning sculptures, cave paintings, and artistic displays. That said, Koyikkal Palace does have a few things that make it unique. I won‚Äôt spoil anything, but there are some interesting elements that are worth checking out. I still encourage everyone to visit it at least once. I went today, and I was the only visitor there üòÖ ‚Äî which actually made the experience even better.You can ask the staff more about the palace‚Äôs history or even the rumored stories connected to it ‚Äî they‚Äôre usually happy to share. Entry is super affordable: just ‚Çπ30 for adults, ‚Çπ10 if you want to use your phone camera, and ‚Çπ150 extra if you‚Äôre planning to take videos or reels.

So yeah, not mind-blowing, but peaceful, low-key interesting, and worth a visit if you're into heritage spots.

Puthen Malika Palace Museum, also known as Kuthiramalika, is a beautiful and quiet place right next to the Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram. It was built in the 1840s by Maharaja Swathi Thirunal Rama Varma, a king known not just for his rule but also for his deep love of music and the arts.

The name Kuthiramalika means Palace of Horses, and when you look up at the roof you‚Äôll see 122 wooden horses carved into the structure. That detail alone makes the building special, but there is a lot more inside. The palace is a perfect example of traditional Kerala style, with sloping tiled roofs, wooden carvings, and cool stone floors made from a special mix that includes egg white and charcoal.

Inside the museum, each room tells its own story. You‚Äôll see royal thrones, one made of ivory and another of crystal. There are old musical instruments, paintings, chandeliers, mirrors from Europe, and even a wooden tree that makes different musical notes when tapped. A painting by Raja Ravi Varma and life-size Kathakali models are also part of the collection.

The visit is peaceful. A guide walks you through the rooms and explains the history, helping you imagine how the royal family once lived here. The museum doesn‚Äôt feel crowded, and the calm atmosphere makes it easy to enjoy. The tour takes about one to two hours.

Photography is not allowed inside, but you can take pictures outside if you pay a small fee. The museum is usually closed on Mondays and opens in the afternoon.

If you are interested in Kerala‚Äôs royal history, traditional architecture, or just want to see something different and beautifully preserved, this palace is definitely worth visiting.

Puthen Malika Palace Museum, also known as Kuthiramalika Palace, is a historic landmark located in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. Built in the 19th century by Maharaja Swathi Thirunal Balarama Varma, a revered ruler and composer of classical music, the palace is a fine example of traditional Kerala architecture with its distinctive wooden structure and intricately carved detailing.

The palace is renowned for its architectural elegance, featuring a blend of traditional Kerala and European styles. Its name, "Puthen Malika," translates to "New Mansion," and it reflects the Maharaja‚Äôs aesthetic sensibilities. The building showcases a unique sloping roof, ornate wooden pillars, and detailed carvings that capture the grandeur of the era.

As a museum, Puthen Malika Palace offers visitors a glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of the royal family. The museum houses an impressive collection of artifacts, including royal memorabilia, antique furniture, traditional Kerala art, and historical manuscripts. The exhibits are meticulously curated to provide insights into the cultural and historical context of the time.

The palace also features a beautiful courtyard and several rooms that have been preserved to reflect their original condition, including the Maharaja's personal chambers and the music room where he composed many of his renowned pieces.

Visitors to Puthen Malika Palace Museum can enjoy guided tours that reveal the rich history and cultural significance of the palace. The museum serves as a testament to the artistic and architectural heritage of Kerala and continues to attract history enthusiasts and tourists from around the world.

The Puthen Malika Palace Museum, also known as Kuthira Malika, is a remarkable place to visit, especially for those interested in the history and architecture of Kerala. Here‚Äôs a five-star review highlighting its features:

### ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ Puthen Malika Palace Museum

**A Fascinating Glimpse into Kerala's Royal Heritage**

The Puthen Malika Palace Museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in the rich history and culture of Kerala. Nestled in the heart of Thiruvananthapuram, this stunning palace, also known as Kuthira Malika, offers an exceptional journey through the opulent lives of the Travancore royal family.

**Architecture and Ambiance:** The palace is a brilliant example of traditional Kerala architecture, with intricate wood carvings and beautiful courtyards. The name "Kuthira Malika" means "Mansion of Horses," named after the 122 wooden horses that adorn the eaves of the palace. The craftsmanship and attention to detail in the design are awe-inspiring.

**Collections and Exhibits:** The museum houses an impressive collection of royal artifacts, including paintings, sculptures, weapons, and antique furniture. Each exhibit is well-preserved and provides deep insights into the lifestyle, culture, and history of the Travancore royals. The musical instruments and traditional attire on display are particularly fascinating.

**Guided Tours:** The guided tours are highly informative, conducted by knowledgeable guides who share interesting anecdotes and historical facts. They bring the exhibits to life with their engaging narratives, making the experience even more enriching.

**Cultural Significance:** Beyond its architectural beauty and historical value, the Puthen Malika Palace is also a cultural hub. It hosts the annual Swathi Sangeethotsavam, a classical music festival honoring the legendary composer Maharaja Swathi Thirunal.

**Overall Experience:** The serene surroundings, coupled with the rich history and artistic grandeur of the palace, make for a memorable visit. It‚Äôs a place where history enthusiasts, art lovers, and cultural aficionados will find immense joy.

In summary, the Puthen Malika Palace Museum is a treasure trove of history and culture. Its exquisite architecture, diverse collections, and engaging tours make it a five-star destination in Kerala.

sources.snippet: Trivandrum Golf Club is located at Kowdiar in Thiruvananthapuram district, Kerala, India.Trivandrum golf course is laid out in the 1850s during the days of the late Maharajah Sreemoolam Tirunal, is one of the oldest in the country and is more than 150 years old. The royal family of erstwhile Travancore had established this golf course even before the Americans and the Europeans took to the game.The Trivandrum Golf Club is one second oldest golf courses in India dating back 1850‚Äôs.The club building of the Trivandrum Golf Club, a heritage structure which is more than 100 years old and noted for its traditional architecture.The building, of about 7,000 sq.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently had the pleasure of organising the Onam celebration at the Sai Trivandrum Golf Club, for the community of Brio League Centre for Holistic Nutrition. It was a perfect blend of tradition and wellness, with the scenic backdrop of the lush golf course adding a serene touch to the festivities.

The highlight of the event was undoubtedly the Sadya catered by White Damor. It was a grand feast that perfectly captured the essence of Onam. Every dish was authentic, flavorful, and prepared with fresh ingredients. The variety on the banana leaf‚Äîfrom the delicious sambar, rasam, and avial to the sweet ending with payasam‚Äîwas a true treat for the senses. What stood out was the balance of traditional flavors with a healthy twist, which resonated with the Brio League‚Äôs ethos of holistic nutrition.

The attention to detail by White Damor was impeccable. Not only did they ensure the Sadya followed traditional customs, but the portion sizes and the quality of the food also reflected a focus on health and wellness. It was comforting to know that one could indulge in a festive meal without compromising on nutrition.

Sai Trivandrum Golf Club offered the perfect venue for the celebration. Its sprawling greens, peaceful ambiance, and well-maintained facilities made the event even more enjoyable. The team at Brio League did an excellent job in organizing the event, seamlessly blending cultural celebration with their mission of promoting holistic health.

Overall, the event was a wonderful experience, and the Sadya by White Damor was an unforgettable highlight. I look forward to more such celebrations where tradition meets wellness in a beautiful setting like Sai Trivandrum Golf Club.

Nestled amidst lush greenery, the golf club exudes a serene charm, surrounded by towering trees that sway gently in the breeze.
The meticulously manicured fairways stretch gracefully, blending harmoniously with the natural landscape
. A variety of birds, from vibrant songbirds to majestic eagles, add life to the tranquil setting, their melodies weaving into the silence of the rolling greens. The exclusivity of the club enhances its allure, with restricted entry ensuring an atmosphere of peace and privacy. Here, amidst nature‚Äôs embrace, every swing feels like a moment of pure escape, a retreat into a world where elegance meets the untouched beauty of the wild.
Good ambiance... Only members allowed... Archery training by Trivandrum Archery Academy is there....

The staff were exquisite and polite. The atmosphere exudes luxury, offering a quiet and calm experience. If you're anywhere near this place, it's a no-brainer‚Äîespecially if you enjoy connecting with like-minded individuals.

First time i am visiting this golf ground. It was very nice location but management was not that much closer to others common peoples. They are very strict and little rudeness in character. Canteen food quality also good. Very cool atmosphere. They maintain the surrounding neet and clean. Restroom also hygienic.

I had a wonderful experience here. The calm and peaceful atmosphere made it the perfect place to unwind. The well-maintained greens and friendly staff added to the charm. It‚Äôs a great spot to enjoy a relaxing game amidst nature. Definitely worth visiting!

It's a quiet preserve in the heart of the city. Trees abound and there are nooks and crannies where you can sit and watch people take up their golf clubs for the first time and practice driving into the nets.

The atmosphere is tranquil and the greens stretch far into the distance. We're here on a weekend and the number of cars probably exceeds the number of players

The rooms are big with high ceilings laid out with wooden planks. The balconies are a good place to take in the view.

Not much choice in terms of food but a hot cuppa tea in the morning makes more sense than most other things in life.

We wandered around the environs and came across a swing with a thin log, not a plank. In most places, when an adult takes to the swing, it looks incongruous. But we were saved by the lack of an audience, even though I took a tumble by trying to step off too soon!

This is one of the oldest Golf Clubs in the continent. One will be really amazed to find something like this in the midst of the city. You can see shades of chinese architecture in the buildings and arena in the club too. However, they are poorly maintained. It isn't open for public but one can book it for function/parties and so on.  The atmosphere is calm and pleasant. There is a cafe, and there are also suit rooms available.. Pet's are not allowed and ironically, one can spot stray dogs here and there.

reviews.reviewText: Kerala Greenery is undoubtedly the best tour operator in Kerala! We booked one of their luxury family tour packages, and every detail was flawlessly executed. Our trip was seamless, stress-free, and truly memorable. Friends have also raved about their Kerala honeymoon tours, making them the perfect choice for couples seeking a romantic getaway. Whether you‚Äôre planning a dreamy honeymoon or an unforgettable family vacation, Kerala Greenery is the go-to expert. Thank you for making our Kerala experience so special!

I had an incredible experience with Kerala Greenery. They offer the best tour packages for couples in Kerala, perfect for a romantic getaway. Their Kerala honeymoon tours are well-organized and cater to every little detail. We loved the mix of luxury and natural beauty in the deluxe tour packages in Kerala. Highly recommend them as the best tour operator in Kerala!

Our corporate retreat organized by Kerala Greenery was a resounding success. They managed to seamlessly blend team-building activities with leisure, providing a well-rounded experience for our team.Kerala Greenery's expertise in handling group tours was evident, and we look forward to partnering with them for future events.

Our cultural tour of Kerala with Kerala Greenery was enlightening. We explored historic sites, attended traditional dance performances, and visited local markets. The guides provided in-depth information about Kerala's history, art, and traditions, making the experience immersive. The accommodations reflected the local architecture, adding to the authenticity of the trip. Kerala Greenery's attention to detail and passion for their culture were evident throughout the tour. We returned home with a deeper appreciation for Kerala's rich heritage.

Excellent experience.  Professional and well organized.

The tour was well organized, from the time that we landed at Kochi airport, to the time that we were dropped off on our last day.

As per the schedule, all items in our itinerary were covered, all accomodations were of acceptable, if not superior standards and the locations covered were exceptional.  The houseboat ride was probably the highlight of the tour.

A very special thanks go to our driver and friend, Mr. Unni, who was a very patient and friendly individual.  He took every precuation possible to ensure that our journey was safe, and made an extra effort each time to drive carefully in order to ensure the safety of the passengers.

As for suggestions, our only request is that we be prepared with the details of each activity in advance.  As an example, it would have helped us if we were informed beforehand that the boat ride on the Thekkady wildlife sanctuary would involve wearing life-jackets and that the seats would be pre-allocated at the time of purchasing the tickets.  Our expectations of the boat ride was also very high, and were disappointed that we were unable to see the kind of wildlife that we were expecting.  This caused a minor inconvenience during our trip, and could have been avoided if we were informed beforehand.

Overall though, it was a very memorable trip that we will cherish for a very long time.
If you're looking for the best tour operator in Kerala, KeralaGreenery is the one! They curated the perfect Kerala tour package for us. Unforgettable experience!

It was a super trip. Kalathil Resort was a nice stay.
Our Cab driver Mr. Unni was so friendly and guided through all tourist spots.
House boat stay was also nice.
Food in both resort and house boat were excellent.
My point-of-contact Subhash was reachable at anytime through Whats app and cleared all my travel related inquires instantly.

The only glitch was that, the Aqua Serene houseboat was bad compared to other house boats which I saw there. There is no entertainment. Made me felt like should have choosed some other House boats.

Overall it was a great trip and we didn't felt like roaming in our own city :)

SIR, We have got in touch through Mr. subash, from the day one he was very helpful and flexible. what our i doubt i got he explain and also given all concessions available and made our trip a tailor made. one. the cab drivers are very caring and helpful. we won' t forget the driver who have taken us even in day like Onem. the boat people are very friendly and facilities in boat is also good. One thing we want to knew that r u arranging trip like this in karnataka and AP?. thank u sir

Thiruvananthapuram (or Trivandrum) is the capital of the southern Indian state of Kerala. It's distinguished by its British colonial architecture and many art galleries. It‚Äôs also home to Kuthira Malika (or Puthen Malika) Palace, adorned with carved horses and displaying collections related to the Travancore royal family, whose regional capital was here from the 18th‚Äì20th centuries.
Named for the 122 carved horses in its walls, this 1840s palace features a museum & guided tours.

Vizhinjam is an area located in the city of Thiruvananthapuram, the capital city of the state of Kerala in India. which belongs to Thiruvananthapuram Corporation. It is located 16 km south west from the city centre and 17 km south of Trivandrum International Airport along NH66. Wikipedia.
Palace museum with art & artifacts from the royal family, plus an annual courtyard music festival.
Traditional 2-story Kerala palace, built in 1677, with folklore & numismatics museums & tours.

Dedicated to Lord Vishnu it is one of the oldest, most popular, and wealthiest temples in India. This is one of the main landmarks in Trivandrum.

Visiting sacred Sree Padmanabhaswamy temple is a  complete bliss!!!
One of the oldest and richest shrines of Lord Vishnu, one can witness the lord in anantashyana posture through three doors of this temple. The architecture, divine energy and rich Kerala tradition well witnessed in this sacred place.

Tips for a pleasant visit:
1. Strict dress code to be followed by devotees ( traditional dress for women and only dhoti with towel for men) Shirt and T-shirts are not allowed
2. Temple dharshan timings are quite different from other temples....plan accordingly
3. Early morning Dharshan is less crowded, otherwise there is a waiting period of 1-2 hours as per crowd
4. Special VIP dharshan tickets are available only in-person inside the temple
5. Cloak rooms are available to keep valuable and cloth
6. It is nice to visit the nearby Ganesha temple along with it
7. There are four gates to enter, the east gate is more crowded.

The intricate carvings and stunning deities created a sense of tranquility, allowing me to connect with my spirituality. The priests were warm and welcoming, offering insightful guidance and blessings. The community's dedication to preserving traditions and serving devotees is truly commendable. I felt a deep sense of peace and gratitude during my visit. Highly recommended for those seeking spiritual growth and connection.

I visited the temple during the weekend on a Saturday in July month. Instantly fell in love with the atmosphere and calmness inside and around the temple. It's really a divine place and you get to see the lord Vishnu in a resting posture and the spirituality, architecture, cleanliness, security and the experience is top notch.

I took the vip darshan with a ‚Çπ500 ticket and with this you can get the closest to the idol. I went at 8 am and you can enter through any of the four gates. Tickets are avilable inside the temple. After security check at the entrance head straight to the ticket counter and then joined the queue. Within 30 mins I was infront of lord Vishnu and asked for his blessings. No rush, no pushing and ample time in front of the idol was allowed. Post the darshana, I got prasadam which was included in the ticket price. Then visited lord Ganesha as well which is withing the temple complex. My heart and mind was at peace and I sat there admiring the temple architecture and beauty.

Temple timing are displayed at the entrance and special puja ticket of around ‚Çπ3000 is also available. Best time for free darshana is to go early morning when the temple opens at 3am.

Also please note that dress code need to be strictly followed and no electronic item are allowed inside the temple. You get locker and  bathing facility at nominal rates.

Had a very good darshan. I chose the very first darshan timing slot, which was 3:30 to 4:45 AM. Then second darshan slot is 6:30 to 7:30 amd so on. Kindly see the suitable darshan timing on website and then visit accordingly to avoid the closure of gate(patt). There is a dress code, mundu (dhoti) for men and saree or half saree for women. Sri Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is a revered Hindu shrine dedicated to Lord Vishnu, depicted in a reclining posture on the serpent Anantha. Renowned for its Dravidian architecture and spiritual significance, the temple is one of the 108 Divya Desams dedicated to Vishnu. The temple's main deity is composed of 12,008 saligrams, fossilized shells from the Gandaki River in Nepal, and is preserved using a unique Ayurvedic mixture called "Katusarkara yogam" .

The temple is also famous for its treasure vaults, which were discovered to contain immense wealth, including gold, jewels, and artifacts, making it one of the richest temples in the world . In June 2025, the temple hosted a rare Maha Kumbhabhishekam, a consecration ritual conducted after nearly 270 years, marking a significant event in its history .

Visitors are required to adhere to a strict dress code: men must wear a white dhoti with an angavastram, and women should wear a sari. Entry is permitted only to Hindus, as per the Temple Entry Proclamation . The temple opens for darshan at 3:15 am and closes at 7:20 pm, with various slots for prayers and rituals throughout the day .

While the temple offers a profound spiritual experience, some visitors have reported issues such as overcrowding and lack of proper guidance for tourists . Additionally, the temple's treasure vaults have been a subject of legal and spiritual debates, adding to its mystique and intrigue .

Overall, Sri Padmanabhaswamy Temple stands as a testament to Kerala's rich cultural and spiritual heritage, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's deep-rooted traditions and beliefs.

placeMetadata.name: Napier Museum

sources.snippet: Located at the very heart of Trivandrum city is another main attraction popular for its magnificent architecture ‚Äì the Napier Museum. Named after Mr. John Napier, the former Governor General of Madras, who inaugurated the new building, the Indo-Saracenic establishment houses a rare collection of archaeological and historical artifacts, ivory carvings, ancient coins, and ornaments.

sources.snippet: The Napier Museum in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is an exquisite example of Indo-Saracenic architecture. This style fuses Indian, Mughal, and Gothic elements, creating a unique and visually stunning structure. Named after Lord Napier, a former British Governor, the museum is both an art and natural history institution.

reviews.reviewText:
Napier Museum is truly a gem in the heart of Thiruvananthapuram. It‚Äôs a great place to take a relaxed walk, unwind, and enjoy some peaceful moments amidst nature‚Äîeven while being right in the middle of the city. The area is quite spacious, making it ideal for peaceful seating, thoughtful discussions, or simply soaking in the serene atmosphere.

From big to small, famous to local, museums give us places to think, grow, learn, wonder, and feel. Few cultural institutions have remained as important as museums over the decades. They preserve and promote social interests as diverse and unique as the people who visit them‚Äîand Napier Museum is no exception.

A night walk here is something truly special‚Äîthe calm surroundings, the cool breeze, and the beautifully lit pathways create a soothing ambiance that‚Äôs perfect for reflection or quiet conversations.

Whether you‚Äôre looking to reconnect with history, enjoy quiet time outdoors, or just take a refreshing stroll, Napier Museum offers something special for everyone. A must-visit for both locals and travelers alike.

One of the popular museums situated in the heart of the city and within the complex next to the famous Trivandrum zoo. One needs to buy a ticket to enter the museum and there is a paid parking facility available nearby.
The architecture of the museum and the park around captivate anyone very easily to visit it from afar. There are sculptures, displays and paintings inside but a limited experience. The place needs more maintenance and the continuous audio ads disturb the peaceful environment of the park.

Napier Museum: Where History, Nature & Calm Come Together üèõÔ∏èüåøüïäÔ∏è

It‚Äôs an experience that deserves an entire day to truly absorb. Spread across a huge, well maintained space, the place is spotlessly clean and beautifully organized, offering a calm escape right in the city.

The museum itself is free to enter, while the adjoining zoo entry costs just ‚Çπ50, which also includes a locker facility for bags and even plastic bottles a thoughtful touch for keeping the space clean. The zoo is expansive, and right outside, a small caf√© serves as the perfect refresher after a walk.

What makes this venue special is the balance it offers: while the exhibits and zoo engage your curiosity, the grounds themselves invite you to slow down. There are plenty of shaded spots and tree-side seating areas, making it easy to pause, rest, or just take in the serene atmosphere. Despite the outside heat, the entire space feels naturally cooler, adding to the comfort.

Whether you‚Äôre interested in history, looking to enjoy a day amidst nature, or simply searching for a peaceful retreat, Napier Museum is one of those rare places where you can do it all at once.

Atmosphere is nice, nicely maintained garden. Inside is a bit old, some of the beam concrete have already fell down from the ceiling. You can look into the past there are some ancient artifacts. Also there's a dedicated staff to guide us through them. You can take photos but need permission to take videos!!! Idk weird, anyways spend some good time there, won't be disappointing.

The Napier Museum in Trivandrum is a beautiful blend of history and architecture. The Indo-Saracenic design, colorful stained-glass windows, and peaceful garden surroundings create a serene atmosphere. The museum houses fascinating artifacts like bronze idols, ivory carvings, and historical weapons. A short but enriching visit for anyone interested in Kerala‚Äôs cultural heritage.

Napier Museum is a meticulously organized and captivating venue that highlights India's extensive cultural legacy. The museum features ancient statues dating back over 2000 years, alongside an impressive array of coins, sculptures, and weaponry. With a wealth of exhibits to explore, it offers a truly enriching experience. One cannot help but feel immense pride in witnessing the advanced knowledge and creativity of our forebears. The museum is beautifully preserved, complemented by a well-kept landscape surrounding the main structure. Centrally located, it is highly recommended for tourists and students alike to delve into and appreciate history!

"I recently had the pleasure of visiting the Napier Museum in Trivandrum and was thoroughly impressed. The museum is a beautiful example of Indo-Saracenic architecture, and its stunning red and white exterior is a sight to behold.

Inside, the collection is a fascinating journey through Kerala's rich history and culture. The bronze sculptures, ancient musical instruments, and intricate ivory carvings are all beautifully preserved and displayed. I particularly enjoyed the section on traditional Kathakali costumes and the impressive collection of temple chariots.

The grounds surrounding the museum are equally lovely, providing a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle. The lush green lawns, blooming flowers, and the nearby Trivandrum Zoo make for a perfect day out.

The staff were friendly and helpful, and the museum was clean and well-maintained. The Napier Museum is a true gem in Trivandrum, offering a wonderful blend of history, art, and nature. It's a must-visit for anyone interested in the cultural heritage of Kerala.

Nestled in the heart of Trivandrum, the Napier Museum is a graceful blend of heritage architecture and cultural riches. Built in 1880, this red‚Äëbrick Indo‚ÄëSaracenic marvel fuses Gothic gables, Kerala sloping roofs, Chinese minarets, and Italianate detailing - a feast for architecture lovers.

Stepping inside, you‚Äôll discover a treasure trove: over 550 artifacts ranging from temple chariots, bronze idols, Kathakali masks, and ivory carvings to a fascinating Japanese leather shadow‚Äëplay collection depicting the Mahabharata and Ramayana.

History buffs will appreciate the coin gallery boasting more than 5,000 coins from South India, Persia, Rome, and beyond. Highlights include an 8th‚Äëcentury Vishnu idol, the Sword of Velu Thampi Dalawa, and rare bronze and wooden sculptures.

One of the most charming features is the museum‚Äôs natural air‚Äëconditioning double‚Äëwalled ventilation and stained glass windows keep it cool even on warm days.

The museum forms part of a fascinating complex alongside the Thiruvananthapuram Zoo (Established in 1857), the Natural History Museum, Aquarium and the Sree Chitra Art Gallery,  enriching your visit with diverse experiences

Tips for your visit:
Visit early on a weekday to avoid crowds, allocate a minimum of 2 hours for the full experience.
Open from 10‚ÄØam - 4:45‚ÄØpm; closed on Mondays and some public holidays.
Tickets are budget‚Äëfriendly: approx ‚Çπ20 for adults (Indian) and ‚Çπ10 for kids.

placeMetadata.name: Kanakakkunnu Palace

sources.snippet: Dipped in the heritage of a bygone era, the Kanakakkunnu Palace blends cultural splendor and human creativity in order to exist as a living representation of the Kerala-Gothic style of the Victorian era. Considered to be constructed by Sree Moolam Thirunal, a ruling Maharaj of Travancore back in 1885, the palace was used for the purpose of entertaining the guests and serving them non-vegetarian food.

sources.snippet: Kanakakkunnu Palace, located in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is a prime example of Victorian-era architecture mingled with traditional Keralan styles. This historic structure is known for its red-bricked walls and white stone dressings. The palace served as the official residence for Sir C.P. Ramaswami Iyer during his time as Dewan.

Such a beautiful place with so much history just left as a garden for people to while away time or lovers to get some space. Sad to see it being like that. It was constructed during the reign of the King of Travancore,  Sree Moolam Thirunal Maharaja, and was used as the guest house for Travancore kings. Presently, it is under the Kerala State Government. It's elegantly designed .

An Amazing Place to Relax, Explore, and Enjoy ‚Äì A Must-Visit Spot in Thiruvananthapuram!

Kanakakkunnu Palace is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places in the city of Thiruvananthapuram. Nestled among greenery and built with stunning architecture, this historic palace is more than just a monument ‚Äì it's an experience. I‚Äôve visited this place many times, and every visit feels refreshing and unique.

The first thing that strikes you is the serene and natural surroundings. The palace is surrounded by sprawling lawns, tall trees, and beautifully landscaped gardens. It‚Äôs a perfect spot to unwind and disconnect from the daily hustle of city life. Whether you're coming here with family, friends, or even alone, there‚Äôs always a peaceful vibe that makes you feel calm and recharged.

One of the biggest highlights of Kanakakkunnu is the ambiance during the evenings and night. As the sun sets, the palace and the entire grounds are lit up beautifully, giving it a royal and almost magical charm. The soft lighting, the quiet surroundings, and the cool breeze create a soothing atmosphere that's ideal for night walks, casual conversations, or simply enjoying the beauty around you. The night vibe here is highly recommended, especially if you enjoy peaceful, scenic places with character.

Apart from just relaxing, Kanakakkunnu also serves as a cultural hub. Many art exhibitions, cultural events, and traditional programs are held here throughout the year. During festivals or special occasions, the palace comes alive with music, lights, and activities ‚Äì it‚Äôs a great way to experience Kerala's rich culture and traditions.

There are plenty of open areas where you can sit and enjoy the view, read a book, or even have a casual picnic. The whole campus is clean and well-maintained, which shows the effort taken by the authorities to preserve its beauty. It‚Äôs also a popular spot for photography lovers ‚Äì the combination of old architecture and natural scenery offers the perfect backdrop.

Another thing I really appreciate is how accessible and welcoming the place is. There is good parking space nearby, and small stalls outside sell tea, coffee, and snacks, making it convenient for visitors. Entry is usually free or minimal, and it's safe even during the night, which is a big plus.

Overall, I would say Kanakakkunnu Palace is not just a tourist attraction ‚Äì it‚Äôs a peaceful retreat, a cultural hotspot, and a heritage landmark all in one. It‚Äôs a must-visit place for anyone in or around Thiruvananthapuram, whether you are a local resident or a tourist. If you have a few free hours in the evening or want to explore something beautiful and relaxing, this is the place to go.

Kanakakunnu Palace grounds are truly refreshing for a morning walk. The entire area is beautifully maintained with clean walking paths, lush greenery, and fresh air. You can see many walkers, joggers, and families enjoying the serene atmosphere early in the morning.

The palace premises have ample space to walk peacefully without crowding, and the natural surroundings with tall trees, flowering plants, and chirping birds create a calm and energetic start to the day. There are benches to rest and shaded areas if you want to sit for a while and relax.

One of the best places in Trivandrum city to connect with nature, refresh your mind, and begin your day positively. Highly recommended for morning walkers, yoga practitioners, or anyone who loves a calm outdoor space within the city.

Kanakakkunnu Palace is one of the most beautiful and calm places in Thiruvananthapuram. Surrounded by greenery and fresh air, it‚Äôs a perfect spot to relax, go for a walk, or simply enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. The palace grounds are well-maintained and spacious, making it a favorite spot for families, morning walkers, and tourists alike. Cultural programs, exhibitions, and festivals are often hosted here, which bring the place to life with colors and traditions. It‚Äôs also very close to other important attractions like the Napier Museum and Zoo, so you can easily explore the area. If you are looking for a mix of history, nature, and culture in the city, Kanakakkunnu Palace is definitely worth a visit. üåø‚ú®

Vizhinjam Rock-Cut Cave, located near the coastal town of Vizhinjam in Thiruvananthapuram district( Near to vizhinjam police station ) This small yet significant cave is renowned for its ancient rock-cut sculptures and inscriptions, making it a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, archaeologists, and tourists.The Vizhinjam Rock-Cut Cave dates back to the 8th century AD and is believed to have been built during the reign of the Ay dynasty, a prominent ruling dynasty in southern Kerala. The cave temple reflects the early phase of Dravidian architecture and serves as an important relic of the region's ancient history. The sculptures and inscriptions found within the cave provide valuable insights into the religious practices, artistic styles, and cultural influences of that era.

placeMetadata.name: Koyikkal Palace

sources.snippet: Koyikkal Palace located in Nedumangad, Thiruvananthapuram is a living symbol of the extravagance of traditional architecture which prevailed in Kerala during the Seventeenth century. It is a double-story palace built in the conventional Nalukettu architectural style of Kerala for Umayamma Rani, the regent of the Venad Royal family between 1677 and 1684. It currently hosts a Folklore and Numismatics Museum with a rich antique collection.

The building itself is this beautiful old Kerala-style structure with sloping tiled roofs and wooden beams‚Äîsuper traditional and photogenic. You can literally feel the history in the air. It was built way back in the 1600s.

Inside, there are museums. The Folklore Museum has some really cool stuff like old musical instruments, traditional lamps, costumes, and even tools people used ages ago. The gardens around the palace are also nice, and it‚Äôs a great spot if you‚Äôre into photography, culture, or just want a chill outing away from the usual city spots.

Koyikkal Palace, Trivandrum

Koyikkal Palace, located in Nedumangadu, near Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is a historical palace built in the 17th century for Umayamma Rani of the Venad royal family. This traditional Nalukettu-style palace is known for its unique architecture and serves as a historical and cultural museum under the Kerala State Archaeology Department.

The palace houses two museums:

1. Folklore Museum ‚Äì Showcasing traditional musical instruments, household utensils, and rare manuscripts that provide insights into Kerala‚Äôs cultural heritage.

2. Numismatics Museum ‚Äì Displaying an extensive collection of ancient coins, including the rare Ottaputhan, Kaliyugarayan Panam, and coins from the Roman and Mughal periods.

Surrounded by lush greenery, Koyikkal Palace is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and those interested in Kerala‚Äôs royal past.
Calm and piece full atmosphere to spend at cheap cost. A well maintained palace and its pride to us. We can spend much more time we want. For me it was wonderful experience

To be honest, I might‚Äôve been a bit influenced by the stories and rumors, but I didn‚Äôt really find anything extraordinary about this palace. It mostly feels like a regular exhibition. If you‚Äôve been to the Keralam History and Heritage Museum, the vibe is pretty similar ‚Äî except the Keralam Museum has more stunning sculptures, cave paintings, and artistic displays. That said, Koyikkal Palace does have a few things that make it unique. I won‚Äôt spoil anything, but there are some interesting elements that are worth checking out. I still encourage everyone to visit it at least once. I went today, and I was the only visitor there üòÖ ‚Äî which actually made the experience even better.You can ask the staff more about the palace‚Äôs history or even the rumored stories connected to it ‚Äî they‚Äôre usually happy to share. Entry is super affordable: just ‚Çπ30 for adults, ‚Çπ10 if you want to use your phone camera, and ‚Çπ150 extra if you‚Äôre planning to take videos or reels.

Recently got to know that one of the lavish home in Kerala is designed by S Square Architects Pvt Ltd.

Every corner of this palatial villa designed by S Squared Architects sparkles with natural elements‚Äîfrom flora and fauna to stonework and water features‚Äî making it an instantly inviting and breathtaking home.

The bungalow built on a six acre property in Trivandrum consists of a semi basement, three floors and a high roof attic. The semi basement houses all the service needs of the house including the electrical rooms, parking spaces, pool tank etc. The bedrooms, living spaces and den are housed on the first and second floor. The most vibrant space of the house is the attic converted into a recreational area dotted with chess and cards table, gaming stations and billiards board. There is also a small pantry for game nights. The piece de resistance is the ceiling which is hand-painted to resemble a vintage map. The flooring makes use of the leftover wood from the construction. A look out balcony on this floor comes with awe-inspiring views of the Indian ocean.

A central courtyard separates the more private spaces from the formal drawing room meant for guests. The five en-suite bedrooms are accessible through foyers from the central courtyard. There is a grand library on the second floor with a home office placed within.

The crowning glory of the house is the indoor swimming pool. ‚ÄúThis is the activity hub of the house with framed views from the dining room, living room, kitchen and the master bedroom. The gym also opens out into this space. There is an interesting bar at the corner. The pool is naturally lit with a skylight that allows the morning light to filter in bestowing upon it a magical sun kissed aura that defines the start of the day. It is an oasis of peace and relaxation for the inhabitants and creates a dramatic escape from the busy life.

Prioritising high-quality materials over ornamentation, the designers wove a sense of bespoke craftsmanship into each room. ‚ÄúWe had to acclimatise the design to respond to challenges of the local climate and locally available materials and construction techniques. A skin wall was added to the exterior walls to protect it from the harsh Kerala sun and rain.

A heavy cornice work at the edge of the sloping roof not just conceals the rainwater gutter but also minimises impact of rainwater on the walls. The sandstone slabs left over from the indoor swimming pool flooring was used for the cracked effect flooring of the gazebo reducing wastage of material. The semi basement of the house has been camouflaged using a gently sloping mound of lush green lawn and graceful curved masses of mixed planting which creates a stunning contrast to the honey coloured walls. It‚Äôs a quirky house: asymmetrical and interesting, with surprises around every corner.

Srijit Srinivas Architects is a professional architecture firm. Mr. Srijit Srinivas is the Architect who designed my family's house. The first and only design proposed by Srijit Srinivas met our expectations and reflected the details of our detailed discussions. His commitment and passion for his own designs and towards our Project was palpable in the detailing on safety, simplicity and aesthetics that he gave to our house. We are profoundly delighted by the final work product and the serene and calm environment he created for his architectural baby, which we now call our home. While his rationale for retaining a professional identity as an Architect for his firm is well justified and therefore, dependence on and choice of external civil construction agencies, Srijit might wish to consider a growing expectation from his prospective clients to identify a committed self sustaining civil engineering team as part and parcel of his own firm - who will have the ability to read his marvellous designs and convert them into elegant rational forms.

Very happy to have been associated with Srijit for our own Project. It is a relationship that we as a family have built beyond Srijit's professional prowess. I would thoroughly recommend Srijit Srinivas as a thinking professional architect, if you are ever in search of one.

The feeling we get because of the rumbling of the water in the pond in the back of my ears and the full greenery seen through the large open main doors when sitting in one of the chairs in the dining hall is the most satisfying and relaxing thing we get and when this happens in a cloudy and rainy day it‚Äôs like an extra icing on the top as seeing rain is one of my hobbies.
Yes really it‚Äôs so so so pleasing and relaxing

When my parents decided to build a third house, unlike the previous times they left it upon us to come up with ideas and find an architect. After an elaborate search on the net, i came across Srijit sirs work and i had this instant gut feeling to go for him.
Once we had an official discussion where we sat down for describing our needs and purposes, which he wholeheartedly accepted , we were all immensely happy.
All he said was ‚ÄúNow leave everything to me‚Äù and from there on he took the full responsibility of getting our dream house completed on time even when the Covid situation was prevailing.
I would say i have rarely come across a person with such clarity of thoughts and extra ordinary visualisation! Both of these virtues makes an architect  stand out from the rest.
though its been 2 years since we moved to our new home , its still as special as it was on day one. All credits go to the Architect himself. üôåüèª

Have worked with Srijit in building my new house.  It's not often that we see an architect who keeps the barrier so high for himself in everything he does in the project.  Srijit always comes out with minimal and neat, yet in-vogue /head-turning designs. Aesthetics is his forte and he does micro detailing  to levels which baffles one.

On hindsight, one of the best things I have ever done is to have resisted the urge to  provide "client's gyaan" to Srijit on his design choices!  Each time we (my wife and myself) felt the urge to 'improvise' on Srijit's design/aesthetics related related choices - we did not press for it.
"Let us leave it to Srijit, he should be right" - was our refrain.  Once the house was completed, we realised how right and wise - we were!

In short - Leave it to Srijit. He will help you build a beautiful home :)

reviews.reviewText:
Discover the essence of Kerala's rich history and heritage at this incredible museum! Keralam Museum is a hidden gem that takes you on a fascinating journey through the state's cultural, social, and artistic evolution. The exhibits are thoughtfully curated, with engaging displays and informative descriptions. The museum's architecture and ambiance are equally impressive, creating an immersive experience. Highlights include the vibrant traditional Kerala art, ancient artifacts, and insightful stories of the region's history. A must-visit for anyone interested in exploring the depths of Kerala's heritage. Well-maintained, friendly staff, and great value for money. Don't miss this treasure trove of Kerala's history.
Ticket - ‚Çπ20

Keralam- Museum of History and Heritage showcases Kerala‚Äôs rich culture through artifacts, sculptures, traditional woodwork, and ancient manuscripts. It highlights the diverse history including its art, architecture and tribal traditions. The museum offers an engaging, immersive experience into Kerala‚Äôs vibrant cultural legacy and historical evolution. The ticket rate is 20 for the adults and it was Worth it!

Best place to know more about Ancient Kerala's socio-economic and religious culture. They have used advanced technological aids to provide more background information of these periods. Even recreated models are present which makes us not just see them but also experience it.

The Keralam Museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the lifestyle and culture of Kerala, both in ancient times and in the modern era. The replica of early human life and cave paintings are truly impressive ‚Äî they help you imagine how people lived thousands of years ago. There are many beautiful and surprising sculptures that reflect the skill and creativity of Kerala‚Äôs artists over the centuries. The museum is well-organized, with detailed displays showing everything from traditional tools and costumes to modern-day cultural highlights. It‚Äôs a perfect place for anyone curious about Kerala‚Äôs rich heritage, and the experience leaves you with a deeper appreciation for how life has changed and evolved over time.

Had a great collection of cultural and ancient artifact's.... Affordable ticket rates...replica of Traditional kerala homes and rooms are built inside as part of the exibition which gives a chance to walk through the history and feel the past.. no lifts are available. Accessibility features are not available here...

A good one for Museum lovers. Great collection with trivia.
The ticket price was minimal and the staff was cooperative. It was a little hot and no source of water. So carry your water bottle.
If you are coming try to come early so you can explore the nearby zoo and another museum too.

A very good and informative museum that tells the story of the people of Kerala from the ancient times. The artefacts and replicas are good. A must for all who are interested in history and heritage. There are interactive touchscreens that explain the exhibits. Ticket price is Rs20.

This is the best option for archeological students. This museum was settled by 4-5 sections That had musical instrument of kerala, murals of kerala, architecture of kerala etc.There are even centuries old objects here.The history of Kerala is very well documented here in various sections. The ticket rate is only 20 rupees for one adult.They maintain this museum clean and neat.The objects are arranged here in a very orderly manner. Must visit place for museum lovers. This musuem is opposite in trivandrum Napier museum. This museum is mainly aims the kerala history and architecture. They are arranged in two floors.

St. Mary's Cathedral Pattom stands as a symbol of spiritual significance and architectural elegance in the heart of Pattom. As I stepped into its serene ambiance, I was immediately captivated by its grandeur and historical resonance.

One of the cathedral's notable features is the Samunaya Ignathios Centre, which serves as a hub for community gatherings, cultural events, and religious ceremonies. It fosters a sense of togetherness and belonging among parishioners and visitors alike, adding depth to the cathedral's role beyond its religious functions.

The presence of the tomb of Mar Ivanios, a revered figure in the Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church, adds a profound sense of reverence and historical significance to the cathedral. It serves as a reminder of the rich spiritual heritage and tradition that the cathedral embodies, inviting visitors to reflect on the legacy of faith and devotion that has been passed down through generations.
