reviews.reviewText: The church is a sight to behold during the festive season, with its stunning lights and peaceful atmosphere, attracting visitors from far and wide.

The building is from early 1900s, made of granite and teak with a large nave, side aisles, bell tower, both transepts, with the chancel serving as the pulpit. The worship is more Presbyterian/Protestant in nature.
Divine services in English are held every Sunday at 10:00 am, the Divine service in Tamil is held at 7:00 am and three Malayalam Divine services take place at at 6:00 am, 8:30 am and 4:30 pm.
There're morning services daily at 7:00 am.
The church tends to be packed for the Sunday 8:30 and 10:00 am services.
The church offers excellent parking facilities.
Disabled access is available by the side aisles.

The Mateer Memorial Church is a Protestant church located in Thiruvananthapuram, India. It is under the Church of South India. It was built in December 1906, and is named after Rev. Dr. Samuel Mateer, a Scottish missionary who was instrumental in the establishment of the church.

The church is a beautiful example of the Gothic Revival style of architecture. It has a tall spire, pointed arches, and stained glass windows. The interior of the church is spacious and airy, with a large central nave and several side aisles.The atmosphere inside the church is serene and peaceful, making it the perfect place for quiet contemplation and prayer.

It is also a popular tourist destination, and is often featured in travel guides.

The X'mas fest at MM  Church was a truly magical and heartwarming experience. The church was adorned with festive decorations, twinkling lights, and beautiful nativity scenes, creating a joyful and welcoming atmosphere for all who attended.

The church's history started with the arrival of the Rev John Cox, the first London Missionary Society missionary in Trivandrum, in 1838. At this time local Protestants in Trivandrum worshipped in a church constructed by the Protestant Evangelical Trust in the 1830s. After Rev Cox resigned in 1861, he was succeeded by Rev Samuel Mateer, who led the church for 30 years and died in 1893. By this time the congregation had grown and needed larger premises and it planned to build a new church building in memory of Rev Mateer. The architectural style used in constructing the church was Hallenkirche (hall church) style. The church building was made in granite, with a square bell tower with a vestibule beneath and a roof supported by gothic arches. The Celtic cross on the bell tower is made of cut stone and commemorates Mateer's Irish background.

The architectural style used in constructing the church was Hallenkirche (hall church) style. The church building was made in granite, with a square bell tower with a vestibule beneath and a roof supported by gothic arches. The Celtic cross on the bell tower is made of cut stone, and commemorates Mateer's Irish background. The church situated near Thiruvananthapuram corporation office and napier museum.

One of the oldest churches comes under the congregational kind in Southern part of India is the Mateer Memorial Church, which is located in the center of Trivandrum, the state capital of Kerala. The church was dedicated on December 1st, 1906. They celebrated its 100th anniversary and is moving forward as MMCSI Cathedral.
Not only this building is a Christian worship place, but also a historical place included in the government records.

The church is a beautiful example of the Gothic Revival style of architecture. It has a tall spire, pointed arches, and stained glass windows. The interior of the church is spacious and airy, with a large central nave and several side aisles.

Building a house has always been a dream for us and Infra I Nova have helped us achieve the dream. I was very skeptical about the construction in my plot due to its irregular orientation. After meeting and discussing with Mr.Christin I was given multiple options of design which helped  see the bigger picture. I really appreciate the design team for bringing forth multiple design options within a short span of time, considering all my requirements and always being available for discussions  and changes. The friendly approach of the entire team definitely helped me in being more comfortable in sharing the ideas I personally have about my house. Coming to the execution part the same friendly and approachable attitude is maintained throughout the process. The only drawback I was even though it was resolved later on was the communication and misinterpretations  during the final stage of the construction. Apart from that I really enjoyed the association  and living in
the  house since 2015 . Thank you for your sincere efforts and contributions. Wishing you for your future endeavors.

Giving 1 star as I don't have an option for 0 stars... Sorry for the long message.

It was during 2022, when I actively started searching for a good interior firm who could do the interior work for my apartment in Trivandrum.
I came across iNova infra from one of the YouTube videos that they published on their account. The Google reviews also suggested more than a 4.75 rating for them at that time!
I went to their office near Infosys (Trivandrum), had multiple discussions, a site visit, and finally handed over the work to them officially during the first week of August 2022.
Also paid the token advance during the second week of August. Till then, everything was going really well.
I was satisfied with the discussions we had, the quick responses to my messages/calls, the site visit they arranged - even though it was an ongoing work.

But things were different from the moment I paid the advance money (or when they got a hint that I was going to be with them for sure).
They started responding really late to my calls/messages (sometimes no response at all), and I was forced to visit their office a number of times to get some updates on the work status.
I was informed that the next steps would be to sign an agreement and also start the design work.
It took almost 3 weeks for them to prepare a draft agreement and also come up with a 'TV UNIT DESIGN' - after a number of follow-up calls/messages, visits, etc!!!
Upon suggesting one correction, it took them another 5 weeks to come back with the corrected TV unit design and a new KITCHEN UNIT design!!!
Again, after a number of calls/messages and 'visits' to their office!!!
Then it again took 3 more weeks for them to come up with a draft pooja unit and a wash unit design‚Äîafter a number of follow-up calls/messages/visits, etc!!!

IN SHORT : the work that they initially assured to complete within 45‚Äì50 days of time period was not even initiated even after 3 months!
The progress they made was that they got the advance money from me and a few draft designs on which multiple corrections were suggested.

Finally, I lost all hope and called it off‚Äîby the end of Nov-2023.

I do have all the proofs (call logs, whatsapp messages, payment receipt, etc) to justify what I have written above.
I was thinking of filing a case against them legally, but I got busy with my apartment work.
Later, decided not to move in that direction and spend more of my time, energy, and more money.. Peace !!!! :)

I hope this review will be helpful for those who try to consider iNova Infra as an option.
From my experience, if you have a lot of time to do the work, then iNova Infra is definitely a good choice. But if you are trying to complete the work quickly, better search for other alternatives.
They did such a great job and were quick and efficient. Also,  completed the project very fast without draining my pocket.i  would definitely recommend to anyone to complete their dreams
First of all, I would say they are very much deserved for this 5 stars! This is one of the best construction company  with good customer services  and excellent works.

They provide consumer friendly service.I fully satisfied with their sincere service . Anybody can trust any work from here...Also it is the most popular company with good budjet prize and interior design.

Reliable builders in Tvm. They excel in every aspects starting from the discussions to the completion of my house.  They provide the best interior designs. Truly dependable top construction company. Thankyou for your service Infra I Nova.

We got Christin's contact from one of my office mate,who explained the details of I nova infra. Once I met Christin, I really got confident about going  ahead with the project in full fledge. He certainly explained to me the life cycle of the whole project  with respect to it's cost and designs. I talked about my choice regarding the selection of materials for the works.
His team Abhiraj and others had developed a wonderful design in our uneven looking plot to make it perfectly cozy.They used cent percent prime quality materials throughout the project according to their specifications. Some additional amount had to be laid down as we selected products of  higher cost other than their spec.
The only hitch I found was that they got one month delayed for completing  my 3100sq ft dream home.
I recommend this design consultancy I nova infra to all as I left  them totally happy and satisfied. And I am living in my üè° home with fullfillment, every day since 2017. Best Wishes .

Mahatma Ayyankali Hall, formerly known as VJT hall located at Palayam, Thiruvananthapuram.
This hall is a cultural heritage and symbol of the olden days in Kerala. Started as Victoria Jubilee Town hall by britishers to commemorate birth anniversary of queen Victoria, the hall later evidenced to several historical moments. Sree Moolam Prajasabha, a parliamentary forum of elected and nominated members assembled here which was organized during Travancore royal rule.
Currently this town hall comes under the cultural Department of state of kerala and named after famous Renaissance leader, Shri. Ayyankali.
Now townhall stages major events in the city including cultural fests, book fests, Art exhibitions, Agro Expos, Handicraft exhibitions etc..
Townhall is easily accessible from the MG road. Only a small parking facility is available inside. Garden infront of the hall looks good.

The VJT Hall is now under the management of Thiruvananthapuram Corporation.
Built to commemorate the golden jubilee of the coronation of Queen Victoria in 1896, the VJT Hall was inaugurated by Sree Moolam Thirunal Rama Varma on January 25, 1896, the hall has witnessed many historical events. Perhaps the most preferred venue for public functions in the city, this monument stands tall as a proud remnant of the colonial era.
By renting this hall solely for commercial trade, the historical importance of the hall is being discounted. Town halls were established in other districts of Kerala as well but these halls continue to host various cultural events.

reviews.reviewText:
Kowdiar Palace is one of the most astonishing landmarks of Thiruvananthapuram city, Kerala.
Situated in a small hillock in Kowdiar, it received its name.
The building is a magnificent two-storied residential structure with 105 rooms and boasts traditional architecture with  a blend of foreign woven to it.
The awe-inspiring palace stands as a testimony of the erstwhile Travancore Royal Family, in which the predecessors of the same are residing.
The palace itself is a granduer and is adorned with lots of artifacts from the erstwhile rulers of the dynasty, including their portraits and other stuff.

Being residential in nature, you have to seek prior permission to visit the premises and to feel its architecture.

Kowdiar Palace is shown open to the public. But unfortunately there in no access to the public. When you are near the gate the police will inform you are not allowed to enter.

Entry to the palace is allowed only twice a year for the kings birthday and death anniversary.

Kowdiar Palace, located in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, is the official residence of the Travancore Royal Family. Built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a wedding gift for his sister, Karthika Thirunal Lakshmi Bayi, the palace remains a significant historical landmark.

Architecture and Features

The palace is a three-story structure with over 150 rooms, showcasing a blend of Kerala and Dravidian architectural styles.

It is set on a lush estate covering about 100 acres, offering a serene atmosphere away from the city's hustle and bustle.

Kowdiar Palace is home to Kerala‚Äôs very first elevator, imported from Italy, and it is still fully operational today.

Current Status

Kowdiar Palace continues to serve as a private residence for members of the Travancore Royal Family.

Entry to the palace interiors is not permitted for the public.

Visitors are welcome to view and admire the palace from the outside, but access beyond the gates is restricted.

Visitor Guidelines

If you plan to visit, you can enjoy the magnificent view of the palace from outside the premises.

Since public entry is not allowed, it is advisable to respect the privacy of the residents and avoid attempting to enter.

Kowdiar Palace stands as a proud reminder of Kerala‚Äôs rich history and cultural heritage, serving as a living testimony to the legacy of the Travancore royal lineage.
Best example for Simplicity even HH were in Royal Status - The Great Travancore Dynasty of South India

Kowdiar Palace is a stunning architectural marvel and a significant historical landmark in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. Built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a gift to his sister, Maharani Karthika Thirunal Lakshmi Bayi, on her wedding, the palace showcases a blend of traditional Kerala and European styles. Here are some fascinating facts about Kowdiar Palace
Architecture: The palace features a three-storied structure with over 150 rooms, lush gardens, and a unique blend of Kerala and European architectural styles.
History Kowdiar Palace served as the royal residence of the Travancore royal family and holds immense historical value, reflecting the region's rich cultural heritage.
Visiting HoursThe palace is open from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM, but entry is restricted as it's the private residence of the royal family. Visitors can observe and photograph the architecture from the gate.
Location Kowdiar Palace is located 4 kilometers from the city center, 5 kilometers from Thiruvananthapuram Central Railway Station, and 7.5 kilometers from Thiruvananthapuram International Airport.
Significance The palace is not just an architectural monument but a testament to the lives and legacy of the Travancore dynasty, which played a crucial role in shaping Kerala's history and cultural identity.

While the palace is not open to the public for interior visits, its exterior and beautifully maintained gardens offer a glimpse into the grandeur and majesty of Kerala's royal past .

The Kowdiar Palace is a historic palace located in Thiruvananthapuram (Trivandrum), Kerala, India. Built in the early 20th century, it served as the official residence of the Travancore royal family.

Architecture and Design
The palace showcases a unique blend of traditional Kerala and European architectural styles:

- *Travancore style*: The palace features traditional Travancore-style architecture, with sloping roofs, wooden ceilings, and intricate carvings.
- *European influence*: The palace also incorporates European-style elements, such as ornate furnishings, chandeliers, and landscaped gardens.

History
The Kowdiar Palace has played a significant role in Kerala's history:

- *Royal residence*: The palace was built in 1934 as the official residence of Maharaja Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma, the last ruling monarch of Travancore.
- *Historic events*: The palace has witnessed several historic events, including the signing of the Travancore-Cochin merger agreement in 1949.

Current Status
Today, the Kowdiar Palace is:

- *Museum*: The palace has been converted into a museum, showcasing the history and culture of the Travancore royal family.
- *Tourist attraction*: The palace is a popular tourist destination, attracting visitors from across the world.
- *Cultural events*: The palace hosts various cultural events and festivals throughout the year, promoting Kerala's rich cultural heritage.

This grand three-storey palace was built in 1934 by Maharajah Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma as a wedding gift for his sister, reflecting both royalty and family pride  . With over 150 rooms, it blends the simple elegance of Kerala architecture with hints of Dravidian influence and even touches of European design like tall steeples and a wooden lift  .

Set on a small hillock and surrounded by lush greenery, the building stands out in the city, its six towers visible from afar  . It was built with respect to Vastu Shastra and oriented to welcome monsoon breezes, showing how practical design and beauty were both important  . Inside, long corridors and high ceilings, carved wooden beams, and large halls hint at the royal gatherings and cultural events that took place here  .

Though visitors can‚Äôt enter, it still feels like walking through history. You can admire the elegant fa√ßade, spot the wood‚Äëlift shaft, and imagine the palace in its heyday. Nearby gardens hold the king‚Äôs burial site, which adds quiet meaning to the place  .

The palace remains the private home of the Travancore royal family, especially the descendants of the Maharajah‚Äôs sister  . Seeing it from the outside gives a sense of Kerala‚Äôs royal heritage, smart design, and how tradition and daily life once united here.

If you drive or walk past, take time to slow down and notice the architecture, the breeze‚Äëfriendly layout, the historical importance, and the idea of home it conveys‚Äîeven without entry, it leaves a memorable impression.

reviews.reviewText:
It is a very nice Science Park. Though please be aware it is only open for educational institutions to visit.   You need to call and book your visit and the park will be open exclusively for you.  As of now they welcome only one group per day.     You are required to report in the morning 09.30am and stay back till evening 4:30pm

The visit involves a lecture-cum-interaction section with Suresh Sir, followed by multiple lab visits.   Each lab the volunteers walk you through a series of experiments, and then lets the kids to do experiments themselves.   There is a lot of enthusiasm from the organizers' side.    One must carry a pen and notebook so that they can note down observations and potential questions.  Finally there is a closing lecture-cum-interaction.

The visit is long. But it is really worth it.    You can take a break in between from experiments and play some small games like darts etc that is set up.

Food is not available in the location.   Either you could carry food or ask Suresh Sir to give some caterer's contact who will serve it.

GREAT EXPERIENCE
I visitee this place when I was studiying in 10th standard and I still feel nostalgic when I think about this placeüíú

The staff will explain the working of the models.If you're going by car or bigger vehicles better park it in the main road and walk up to the place as the road is very narrow and there is no place for parking at the park. You have to call them and fix an appointment before going.

It was a very nice experience for my brother.
Recommended especially for science enthusiastic school kids.

The busiest railway station of the state in terms of daily passengers, Thiruvananthapuram Central, is located at Thampanoor. It caters an average of 40,908 passengers a day, making it as the busiest railway station in Kerala. Wikipedia.

Vellayambalam is a prominent junction in the city of Thiruvananthapuram in the state of Kerala, India. It is situated on the Rajapatha that stretches from Kowdiar to East Fort. This junction connects the arterial roads connecting Kowdiar, Sasthamangalam, East Fort, Thycaud and Thampanoor. Wikipedia.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Thiruvananthapuram, the capital city of Kerala, is a treasure trove of architectural marvels that reflect its rich history and vibrant culture. From the majestic Kanakakkunnu Palace, which once hosted royal gatherings, to the colonial charm of the Trivandrum Central Railway Station, the city offers a unique blend of traditional and contemporary designs. As you stroll through its streets, you'll encounter stunning structures like the Koyikkal Palace and the Rock Cut Cave Shiva Temple, each telling a story of the past while standing proudly in the present.

For those passionate about design, Thiruvananthapuram is home to a thriving community of architects and firms that push the boundaries of creativity. EGO Design Studio and Ellis and Jorim Architects are just a couple of the names making waves with their innovative projects. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast or simply looking to explore the city's hidden gems, Thiruvananthapuram invites you to discover its architectural wonders and the stories they hold. So grab your camera and get ready to explore this captivating city!
